utterances: So this has happened before.
This time, it hadn't happened as quickly as it did with Ginsburg.
Other times we find the information takes a little bit longer to come out.

But I think what's really unprecedented here is to see how much of the president's party and interest groups close to the president really just drew back from this nomination so quickly and just really recoiled from it.
Mm-hmm.
Mara Liasson, David Savage, Michael Gerhardt, stay with us.
We're going to have to take another short break.
White House counsel Harriet Miers this morning withdrew as a nominee to the Supreme Court.
In a letter to the president, Miers wrote that her confirmation process would have presented a burden for the White House.
You can read her entire statement and President Bush's response at our Web site, npr.org.
And we'll have more on this story after the break.
I'm Neal Conan.
This is special coverage from NPR News.
(Announcements)
This is special coverage from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
This morning, Harriet Miers asked President Bush to withdraw her nomination to be on the Supreme Court of the United States.
According to the White House, President Bush accepted that suggestion with reluctance.
With me to discuss reaction and where we go next are NPR political correspondent Mara Liasson and David Savage, Supreme Court reporter for the Los Angeles Times.
Also with us is Michael Gerhardt, professor of law at the University of Chapel Hill in North Carolina.
He's with us from the studios of member station WUNC in Chapel Hill.
And, Michael Gerhardt, if we're back at square one, what's the next step in this process?
Well, the next step obviously is that President Bush has got to sort of recalibrate.
But one thing he's got to think about pretty quickly is the extent to which he wants these interest groups to dominate the nomination process.
I mean, typically, they've tried to influence confirmation outcomes, but now they want to actually influence his particular choice.
He's got to decide the extent to which he looks beholden to them, or the extent to which he's going to try and unify Democrats and Republicans like he did with the Roberts nomination.
And, David Savage, let me ask you a question about timing.

If the president were to make another nomination--presumably it takes him some period of weeks to do that--what I've been hearing is that the Senate Judiciary Committee might not be able to get around to hearings for a nominee till maybe January.
Yes, that sounds right.
And they can say Sandra O'Connor is on the Supreme Court and is filling that seat so there's no hurry.

I think that this would be a--there'd be a lot of reason for President Bush to take his time on this one because, as Michael Gerhardt was saying, there have been some real fiascoes in the past where, you know, Nixon had Clement Haynesworth voted down, they immediately came back and picked Harrold Carlswell.
And then Carlswell had a terrible record.
He had given a series of segregation speeches.
When Robert Bork went down, as Michael mentioned, they immediately came back with Doug Ginsburg and they really hadn't done enough vetting of Doug Ginsburg.
So I think considering what's happened this time, it'd be wise for President Bush to actually take some time and sort of vet the nomination before it goes forward.

Mara, similarly, though, you don't necessarily want too long a time between the announcement of a nomination and the beginning of confirmation hearings for, well, opposition groups, whichever side they may be on, to ferret out whatever's in the background.
Right.
Although you have to assume that whatever's in the background is going to come out.
I mean, you can't assume that if only you just start the hearings--there's going to be a certain period of time between the announcement and the hearings.
You saw the same tug-of-war over Miers that you always see.
Democrats want to wait a little longer, and the Republicans--Specter wanted to start the hearings soon.
But believe me, the date of November 7th, which they set for Miers, was plenty of time for a lot to come out that was harmful to her.
But look, I think that they're going to--whoever he puts up, there's going to be the same--this is the swing seat.
People forget this is the big enchilada here for both the left and the right, and this is going to be a big battle no matter who's put there.
And I don't know.
There's no more Roberts on the short list.
That was the problem he had the first time.
Nobody with a glittering establishment resume, no paper trail on the big hot-button issues and someone who the conservatives will rally around and won't be so provocative to the left.
I mean, I don't know who it is.
Mm-hmm.
Michael Gerhardt, in terms of process, is there anything the White House might want to do differently next time around?
Possible vandals, the kind of stuff around Nalen's job that doesn't always make the headlines.

Oh, as David suggests and as Mara suggests, I think the smart thing for the president to do--and I'm sure he'll try and do this--is he's going to have to sort of take a deep breath, move a little bit more deliberately and they're going to make sure every I is dotted and every T is crossed at this point.
And moving slowly and deliberately is critical; that's number one.
Number two is, I think, is talking with as many senators as possible.
And also, I suspect they're going to reach out to interest groups and try and build up support for this nomination before it becomes public.
That may be a critical feature this time that they didn't do last time.
But I don't know if that's possible.
How do you build up support for a nomination without making it public?
Look at what happened when they tried to have these conference calls to rally support for conservatives.
Everything gets out when you're talking interest groups.
And as you point out--you're right.
As you point out, there's not another John Roberts in the wing and that's another challenge for this administration.
It's going to have to figure out how much of a fight it can handle.
Michael Gerhardt, thank you very much for being with us.
We appreciate your time, as always.
Thank you very much.
Michael Gerhardt is professor of law at the University of Chapel Hill at North Carolina, and he's with us from the studios of WUNC in Chapel Hill, North Carolina.
And let me ask you, David Savage, just at the moment, obviously, there is Sandra Day O'Connor on the Supreme Court of the United States.
She may be the person most disappointed today to find out this nomination is not going to go ahead and she can't retire as she'd hoped to.
But if--going back to that time line, if there aren't confirmation hearings till January, well, she would have heard then most of the cases of this Supreme Court term.
Yes, that's correct.
I had said, I believe on this program and in some other places, that I didn't see why she was there.
It was totally symbolic.
She was--your votes don't count on the Supreme Court until the day the case comes down.
And so I thought, `She's going to be there a month or two, hear a few cases, but her votes won't count in any case.
It's now possible her votes will count and she could be the deciding vote in this big Oregon case on assisted suicide.
She appeared to be very much with Oregon, saying, `This is a decision of the people of Oregon.
If they want to have this Death With Dignity Act, that's their decision.
That decision could be out in January, and it could be a 5-to-4 decision with Justice O'Connor casting the fifth vote.
And while there are no big, you know, definitive abortion cases coming before the court, there could be some of interest to people of both sides of that argument, as well.
Absolutely.

There's one up in late November, a parental notification case, and she will certainly be sitting there for the argument, and we'll just have to how quickly this plays out as to whether she'll actually be there the day that the case is decided.
Joining us now is California senator and Democrat, Dianne Feinstein.
She's with us from her office on Capitol Hill.
Senator, good of you to be with us today.
Oh, thank you.
I wanted to get your reaction to the Miers withdrawal.
Do you see it as an example of the process working?
Well, I was very surprised by it, but it's happened and I think now we've got to go forward and look to the future.
I, for one, hope the president takes his time.
I hope he really does engage in advise and consent.
I think when these nominations do the best is when a president just picks up the phone and talks to members of both sides of the aisle that are on the Judiciary Committee.
President Clinton actually did that with Republicans on the Judiciary Committee, and I think it created an atmosphere in which Clinton's appointments were able to go through very easily.
What we have right now is a very polarized situation and there are many of us that believe that the president will hopefully appoint somebody whose qualifications are well known.
Now that's one of the problems here.
The qualifications of Harriet Miers were really difficult to establish because most of it came during her time at the White House.

And at the White House, she was on the immediate staff of the president of the United States and, therefore, the president did not want to allow any documents to come to the Judiciary Committee so one could take a look at her background.
I think it's fair to say that members did not have any real knowledge of her qualifications other than what's been out there in the press, and it wasn't enough.
Mm-hmm.
Harry Reid, the minority leader, the Democratic leader in the Senate, said today that he thought the Miers nomination was shot down by the extreme right of the Republican Party.
Well, I think there's no question about that.
I've certainly never seen as visceral a campaign against her or against a nominee.
I mean, television ads began and, you know, this is part of her own party.
So I mean, I think it's one end of the political spectrum that rose up and said, `We don't want this nominee.'
Throughout the argument, many in the Democratic Party sort of stayed on the sideline and sort of watched the Republicans and conservatives argue with each other.
But the outcome, some suspect, might be a nominee who might be harder to take on a lot of issues than Harriet Miers was.
Well, I think the president would be poorly advised to proceed in that direction.

The Supreme Court is for all of the people of the nation--liberals, conservatives, mainstream--and I think the president has an obligation to appoint somebody that represents all of America, not just a segment of America.
No one owns the Supreme Court; no one is entitled to an appointment.
If the next nominee is perceived to be an extreme right-winger by you or by others, is this something that the Democrats would be prepared to fight over, have a filibuster over?
Well, you know, the thing about your question is the `if,' which makes it hypothetical, and I don't usually like to answer hypothetical questions.
But obviously, no one is going to stand by and see somebody, as the expression I heard earlier today was, `crammed down our throats.
We're not going to heave to to that, and that's why I think it's particularly important for the president to utilize an advise-and-consent procedure.
You know, there's too much polarization back here.
Let's put an end to it.
Let's try to work together.
There's so many qualified people out there.
And we all know this individual will be Republican.
We all know they'll be conservative.
That isn't the problem.
The problem is whether an individual is extreme and, you know, doesn't meet certain criteria that individuals might hold.
If the White House were to call you and say, `Well, give us a couple of ""for-instances"" of people you think might be well-qualified, conservative members of the Supreme Court'?
Well, I could think of one right now and I haven't--I'll go back and think of more, but you know, one might be Ron George.
He's the chief justice of the California Supreme Court.
It's the largest state Supreme Court.
He's a Republican.
He's well-qualified.
He certainly knows the law.
He certainly has the qualifications.
It's somebody like that--and I don't think he'd have a problem.
Senator Feinstein, thank you very much for being with us today.
Oh, you're very welcome.
We appreciate your time.
Thank you.
Right.
Democrat Dianne Feinstein, who's also a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, and she joined us by phone from her office on Capitol Hill.
Still with us are NPR's national political correspondent Mara Liasson and David Savage, who covers the Supreme Court for the Los Angeles Times.
If you've joined us late and are just trying to figure out what's going on, Harriet Miers, President Bush's nominee to the Supreme Court, this morning withdrew her nomination.
The White House issued a statement where the president said he accepted that decision reluctantly, and we're talking about reaction to it.
You're listening to special coverage from NPR News.
And, Mara, just listening to what Senator Feinstein had to say, Democrats certainly don't have the votes in Congress, in either house and certainly not in the Senate.
At the same time, the White House--the president's ratings are at an all-time low.

I mean, these things change over time, but he's not dealing from a position of strength, and the political background of this is there could be--emphasis on `could be'--indictments of senior White House aides as soon as tomorrow.
The president's approval ratings were bouncing around in the low 40s before he nominated Harriet Miers and they were waiting for indictments then.
There were--all these problems existed then.
And the thinking among some Republicans at the time was, `This isn't very good for us, but just wait till the president sends up a conservative nominee.
We're all going to rally around that nominee.
We're going to have a good, clear ideological fight with the Democrats, split the Democrats again like we did with Roberts, and that would be good for us.
Well, that didn't happen.
